title: Driver faces £5,000 penalty fine for veering into puddle to soak pedestrian
text:

A driver is facing a £5,000 penalty for driving into a puddle - and soaking a pedestrian with a tidal wave of dirty water.

The Stafford-based motorist is currently under investigation and, if found guilty, could face a significant fine for breaking the rules of the Road Traffic Act.

It comes after a video went viral on social media, showing the moment the car veered into a huge puddle in bad weather.

It shows a silver Audi going over a speed bump before accelerating and suddenly veering right to the opposite side of the road where there is large amount of surface water, the StokeonTrentLive reports .

The car then causes a huge wave of dirty water to drench a woman walking past at around 3.44pm on Friday, October 11.

The stunned victim then turns around in shock as the car continues up the road.

(Image: Staffordshire Tactical Information Group / Facebook)

The details have since been passed on to Staffordshire Police to investigate after being posted on a local Facebook page.

The investigation comes as motorists are being advised 'puddle rage' is a crime and anyone who deliberately splashes pedestrians can face a huge fine.

Under section three of the Road Traffic Act 1988, it is an offence to drive ‘without reasonable consideration for other persons’, and this includes any instance of ‘driving through a puddle causing pedestrians to be splashed’.

The maximum punishment is a level five fine of £5,000 in instances where driving ‘amounts to a clear act of incompetence, selfishness, impatience or aggressiveness’.

The more common sanction for splashing a pedestrian would likely be a £100 Fixed Penalty Notice and three points on the licence, but could be boosted into the thousands if the offender chooses to take the case to court.

(Image: Staffordshire Tactical Information Group / Facebook)

RAC road safety spokesman Pete Williams said: “Anyone unfortunate enough to have suffered a drenching by an inconsiderate motorist splashing them when driving through a puddle would probably welcome a sizeable financial penalty for the driver.

"Since 2013 careless driving can be dealt with by a Fixed Penalty Notice with a £100 fine and three penalty points.

"This is a take it or leave it offer for the motorist if they accept that they have committed the offence.

"If, however, they refuse then they will face a magistrate who could impose a fine up to £5,000, although the maximum is very unlikely.

"In such a case the fine would be appropriate to the level of distress and inconvenience caused and would hopefully send a clear message that inconsiderate and potentially aggressive driving is simply not acceptable.

“Drivers have a duty to show respect and care for their fellow road users and pedestrians.”

Amanda Stretton, motoring editor at Confused.com, said: “The rain we’re seeing is causing havoc on the roads, and some people might think that driving through puddles is a bit of fun.

“But puddle rage is actually one of many unknown offences that could land you with a hefty driving fine.

“It’s unsurprising that so many drivers are confused about what is legal and illegal, and what is an on-the-spot fine or not.

“To clear up any confusion, we’ve created a checklist to highlight just how some offences that drivers can be fined for. And, like splashing pedestrians, it can be thousands of pounds.”
description: The video, recorded in Stafford, shows a silver Audi going over a speed bump before accelerating to the opposite side of the road where there is large amount of surface water
